♾ Autism & Disabilities Advocate

node.text:
⭐️Many clinicians struggle with how to go about making Autism assessment referrals- and while there’s no one perfect or correct way to do this, I’m sharing how I have these conversations here! Check out my story highlights for more tips and answers for FAQ! 

I originally made this video as part of @thesltscrapbook Big EI event- it’s still on her IGTV if you are interested in even more early intervention tips!

node.text:
⭐️THIS IS A MUST WATCH & SHARE⭐️ (for adults) 
Stuck at home with your kids and need a laugh? I wrote a poem inspired by the book, “Go the F to Sleep”- called “Covid-19, Just Leave me the F Alone”- 🤣 We miss you already teachers!!! (Lyrics below) Follow @mrsspeechie for daily activities with everyday items to keep your kids busy while learning and playing!

Add your own verse in the comments if you’ve got one! 🤣

It’s 2020, the year of Covid-19. We are all alone with no others to be seen. We are all happily enjoying reconnecting during family time. Hey, we can do this- day one went perfectly fine. Now it’s day 5, please throw me a bone- all I want is for you to just leave me the F alone. 
This morning we played games, you won pop the pig, and laughed when he ate too much. I know you’re hungry, you’ve told me 327 times as such! “Ok, here’s your 23rd snack”, I groan. Now please oh please leave me the F alone. 
Finally, it’s time for you to play by yourself while I scroll Instagram on my phone. Open your applesauce? Your dad is RIGHT EFFING  there! Ok fine, I’ll do it, just promise after, you’ll leave me the F alone.

We snuggle up to read a book, ok fine we can read 8. You’re calm and so quiet I think maybe this day will go great! No, you can’t ride me like a horse, I just spent an hour making you an obstacle course! Go play on it, get in the zone! And just leave me the F alone. 
Finally, you are watching tv, you ate lunch and it’s time to rest. I can get a quiet shower- without you, you pest! Oh no, You’ve got to be kidding me, I don’t care what your brother did- stop making me feel like a croan! Go on, get out and leave me the F alone. 
We learned about the body, we danced to GoNoodle, I think I’ve earned a beer. No, we can’t go to the zoo, we can’t go anywhere but here. No, my eyeballs aren’t cold. My monster’s name is Charlie, I don’t know where you put your pirate gold. That’s cool your bug bite’s name is Fred. I don’t know what day I’m going to be dead. Enough with the 5 million questions, “let’s play the quiet game”, I moan! Go on outside and leave me the F alone!

node.title: Covid-19: Leave Me the F Alone

node.text: Who is doing Monster Monday today?! This is one of my- and my son Kam’s- favorite monster book! Wanna join us in our story time? Grab ANY book and come help us with our Monster!

node.title: There’s a Monster in Your Book read aloud

node.text:
This is our LAST episode for my interview with Shanna, Teague and Lane’s mom. I was thinking about having her come on in my stories more regularly to answer your questions and share her experiences... What do y’all think? Yay or nay? In this episode:

1️⃣ Did she ever feel guilt or shame because her children were different than she expected? 
2️⃣ What advice she would give to a parent new to a diagnosis 
3️⃣ Would she change T & L if she could?
4️⃣ Her last thoughts she wants to share with you all! •
 #slp #slpeeps #speechtherapy #instaslp #slpbloggers #preschoolslp #autism #parents #parenting #toddlers #earlyintervention #specialeducation #ashaigers #sped #iteachtoo #languagedevelopment #speechdelay #slp2be #specialneeds #slpsfollowslps

New interview!! In this one, we discuss- 
1️⃣ Telling friends and family about the boys’ diagnoses. 
2️⃣ Why she agreed to let me share Teague and Lane with the world.
3️⃣ How she felt watching me talking about their videos.
4️⃣ What she feels helps them the most. 
Hope you guys are finding these helpful! Only one more portion of the interview left after today 😭😭

I’m loving all of the feedback from these autism interviews and SO happy these are helping you guys! Feel free to laugh at the cover photo, I did that on purpose 🤣! This interview with Shanna, Teague and Lane’s mom, covers the following questions:
1️⃣ Did you get a second opinion?
2️⃣ Was there anything a professional said or did that helped you accept their diagnosis?
3️⃣ Was there anything a professional said or did that did not help?

node.text:
🎉🙌🏼 The one you’ve been waiting for!! I am excited to share this portion of my interview with Shanna, Teague and Lane’s mom because I know many of you are very interested in hearing about our friendship through the time I shared concerns about Lane until he was diagnosed about a year later. Each time I share one of these, I just well up with pride and gratitude that this amazing woman has been so open and honest with sharing her story. 
We also talk about how she listened to another professional who told her “no way” Lane was on the spectrum, so I urge other professionals to refer to a specialist if anyone brings up autism concerns- this happens WAY more often than you think!

node.text:
Continuing my parent interview with Shanna, Teague and Lane’s mom- I LOVE this one because of the raw honesty she expresses about her emotions! We also covered: 
1️⃣ How Teague and Lane are both on the spectrum but present very differently 
2️⃣ Some of the emotions and “denial” she went through during their early childhood, and thoughts of “he’s just stubborn”, “but he’s so smart”, and “he makes really good eye contact” and some really open and honest conversations about her initial grief and how she feels now 
3️⃣ How Lane got his diagnosis, including me talking about my concerns and giving Shanna the “list” she asked for- and how she responded

I hope these videos are helpful and as always, huge thanks to Shanna for sharing her boys with us all so we can learn AND being so open and honest!

node.text:
I think this might be my favorite clip from my interview with Teague & Lane’s mom, Shanna! It covers a lot of your questions- including:

1️⃣ Were the early signs of Autism easy for her to spot?
2️⃣ What did their pediatrician say, and did the boys pass the MCHAT?
3️⃣ What advice she has for parents who have been told “Wait and see”, or have been made to feel “crazy” for thinking something may be different about their child
4️⃣ How we met & became friends, and a little bit about how she felt when I brought up autism concerns about Lane 
Watch the rest on IGTV!

node.text: You guys have asked for it and I have finally gotten with Teague and Lane’s mom, Shanna, to answer them all!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 16, 2021 tagging @learnplaythrive. May be an image of text that says '3 REASONS TO RETHINK HAND-OVER-HAND ASSISTANCE FOR AUTISTIC CLIENTS 1 2 3 Violates Bodily Autonomy Creates Dependent Routines Covers up for a lack of strengths- based clinical skills earn-Play Thrive OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY Amrs. SPEECHIEP'.

node.text: Pumped to team up with @learnplaythrive today to talk about why we should rethink using hand over hand with our autistic clients! I know it can be hard to unlearn strategies we’ve always used but this is how we grow and do better! Swipe through to read our top 3 reasons and let us know what you think in the comments 👇🏼

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 16, 2021 tagging @learnplaythrive. May be an image of text that says '3 REASONS TO RETHINK HAND-OVER-HAND ASSISTANCE FOR AUTISTIC CLIENTS 1 2 3 Violates Bodily Autonomy Creates Dependent Routines Covers up for a lack of strengths- based clinical skills earn-Play Thrive OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY Amrs. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'RETHINKING HAND-OVER-HAND ASSISTANCE FOR AUTISTIC CLIENTS 1 Violates Bodily Autonomy Autonomy is one of the four principles of the SLP Code of Ethics. Moving a child's body without their permission isn't a prompting strategy; it's a violation of their autonomy. And since autistic kids are at higher risk of sexual assault than their peers, teaching them from the start that adults need permission to access their bodies is paramount. earn-Play Thrive OCCUPATIONAL HERAPY Amrs. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'RETHINKING HAND-OVER-HAND ASSISTANCE FOR AUTISTIC CLIENTS 2 Creates Dependent Routines We know that many autistic kids form routines quickly and can have α hard time changing them once they are formed. Physical prompting is one of the hardest types of prompting to fade. Instead of creating dependent routines, try setting a child up for success with α prompt hierarchy that doesn't include hand-over-hand. _earn-Play Thrive OCCUPATIONAL HERAPY Amrs.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '3 RETHINKING HAND-OVER-HAND ASSISTANCE FOR AUTISTIC CLIENTS Covers up for a lack of strengths-based clinical skills Many therapists use hand-over-hand because they don't know how else to get a child's engagement. Instead of physical prompting, try filling up your tool box with strengths-base and respectful strategies. Modeling without expectation is great for teaching communication. Executive function supports help with initiation. And incorporating a child's interests is a perfect strengths-based way to capture their attention. earn-Play Thrive OCCUPATIONAL HERAPY omrs.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP in Dallas, Texas. May be an image of text that says 'TANTRUMS ARE COMMUNICATION "I DON'T LIKE THIS" "I NEED HELP" "I WANTED THE BLUE CUP" " "I FEEL MAD FRUSTRATED OR UPSET" "I WANT YOU TO COMFORT ME" omrs.SPEECHIEP SPEECHIEP'.

node.text:
I know, I know, I can’t think of an adult who particularly enjoys when children have tantrums. BUT- we need to remember that they are communication - they might express something the child would like to say or perhaps some overwhelming emotions they are processing. 

Believe it or not, tantrums actually benefit children- they can improve learning and even sleep because they release stress, and they can help with emotional regulation abilities. And how we, as adults, respond to tantrums can impact these benefits. Co-regulation, modeling of communication, and providing needed support during these times can make a huge difference in a child’s life! So next time you see a child tantrum - remember, there is a purpose to their behavior. 

*just adding that all kids are different and may need different things at different times. Some children may need some time to themselves while others may need support from an adult - so there shouldn’t be a one size fits all response to tantrums ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021 tagging @the_neurodivergent_teacher. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'HOW DO TEACH COPING AND REGULATION SKILLS? TEACHER omrs. SPEECHIEP'.

node.text:
This week @the_neurodivergent_teacher and I talked alllll about supporting students in a neurodiverse (which includes both neurotypical + neurodivergent students) and a recurring theme was directly teaching coping and regulation skills. So today we are going to talk about how to do that! 

This wraps up our collab and I had so much fun with this one! Let us know if you learned anything helpful and/or what you plan on doing with this new info! 👇🏼

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021 tagging @the_neurodivergent_teacher. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'HOW DO TEACH COPING AND REGULATION SKILLS? TEACHER omrs. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'DIRECTLY TEACHING COPING AND REGULATION SKILLS Children need time and practice to learn coping and regulation tion skills- just like anything else. And they can't learn a new skill when they are overwhelmed or shut down. So we have to: TEACH MODEL PRACTICE LABEL TEACHER omis. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'DIRECTLY TEACHING COPING AND REGULATION SKILLS TEACH: Directly teach coping strategies you want students to implement in your calming corner or relaxation center. Try introducing α new strategy each week and practice it ας a whole class during morning meeting every day Always pair the strategy with a physical object or tool to help make it more concrete and accessible for all students (like five poker chips when taking five deep breaths, for example). TEACHER omis. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'DIRECTLY TEACHING COPING AND REGULATION SKILLS MODEL: Purposefully model and show students how you engage in a specific coping strategy; verbally label when you are feeling like when you need to use a strategy; model choosing a strategy from the calming corner or relaxation center when you need it. For example, the adult may say, "I feel frustrated because what am trying isn't working the way want it to. I'm going to get one of my tools from the calm corner to help me feel better. omrs. SPEECHIEP FACHER'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'DIRECTLY TEACHING COPING AND REGULATION SKILLS PRACTICE: Give students ample opportunities to practice coping skills and regulation strategies when they are calm, both by themselves and with an adult to model; make your calming corner or relaxation center easily accessible and frequently visited to aid in practicing these skills. This makes the coping space a familiar and comfortable place, and decreases the stigma of its use. TEACHER omis. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'DIRECTLY TEACHING COPING AND REGULATION SKILLS LABEL: As much as possible, abel when you notice student showing you signs they might be dysregulated (privately, kindly, and nonpunitively). Remind them that they can access the calming corner or relaxation center at any time, and it might help them feel better Offer to go there with them and use strategies together. TEACHER Amrs SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'STRUCTURE COPING STRATEGIES so THEY ARE EASILY ACCESSIBLE TIP1: TIP Create ways to practice coping skills that have a clear, concrete beginning, middle, and end. Instead of "squeeze this stress ball,' try "here are five stress balls. We're going to squeeze each of them, and then place them in this finished bin." This can also help prevent students getting stuck in this space doing an enjoyable activity instead of transitioning back to their work. TEACHER amrs. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'STRUCTURE COPING STRATEGIES so THEY ARE EASILY ACCESSIBLE TIP 2: Incorporate interests: coping and regulation is not just deep breaths. Think about what you find calming when you're upset: breathing helps, but so does a fun activity to get your mind unstuck and unwound Include tasks and activities that are enjoyable and calming for students, like reading a book, listening to music, coloring, blowing bubbles (great for breathing, too!), using sensory/stimmy toys, etc. TEACHER omis. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'THINGS TO AVOID WHEN TEACHING COPING SKILLS: Expect students to know how to use strategies you haven't taught them Expect students to learn new calming strategies when they are already escalated Force a student to go to the calming corner or relaxation center or turn it into a "time out" or punishment Expect students to self-regulate before they have ample opportunities to practice strategies when calm and engage in co- regulation when escalated TEACHER omrs SPEECHIEP'.

Photo shared by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021 tagging @the_neurodivergent_teacher. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TIPS FOR USING A CALMING CORNER: A calming corner is a designated space in a classroom (or home!) for a child to go to both practice coping skills and regulation strategies regularly and as a safe space to go when they feel strong emotions and need to regain emotional and physical control. It is often equipped with tools to promote coping and regulation, including sensory materials, preferred calming activities, and structured regulatory tasks. TEACHER omis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

node.text: Today’s post with @the_neurodivergent_teacher is about calming corners! I think the biggest mistake made when it comes to these is that adults think they can just send kids to a calming area and the child will magically calm down. But that’s not how it works! We need to directly teach strategies - and we need to do this regularly and when the child is regulated and able to learn! ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021 tagging @the_neurodivergent_teacher. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TIPS FOR USING A CALMING CORNER: A calming corner is a designated space in a classroom (or home!) for a child to go to both practice coping skills and regulation strategies regularly and as a safe space to go when they feel strong emotions and need to regain emotional and physical control. It is often equipped with tools to promote coping and regulation, including sensory materials, preferred calming activities, and structured regulatory tasks. TEACHER omis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'TIPS FOR USING A CALMING CORNER: Have students visit the calmng/break center regularly (on a schedule), ideally every day, but 2-3x/week in larger classroom settings is ok. This helps students practice these skills regularly when calm and well-regulated, prevents it from being a space where "bad kids" go, and helps prevent it becoming a special, fun "escape" space during work times. Provide a to-do list of strategies for students to practice when they take their scheduled visit to the break/calm calm center to help them master coping/regulation skills. Amrs.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TIPS FOR USING A CALMING CORNER: •Directly teach and practice coping skills and regulation strategies to use in the calming/break center during whole- or m”l-group lessons. Once skills have been taught, add them to the break/calming center. Do not add activities/strategies to this space until they have been directly taught and practiced with teacher/adult direction. You can recommend a student transition to the calming/break center, but it should not be used αs a forced "time out" area. TEACHER Amis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TIPS FOR USING A CALMING CORNER: Allow students to go to the calming/break calming center whenever they need. Talk to students about what signs might indicate they need to visit (feeling overwhelmed or frustrated, being extra silly to the point of being unsafe, hitting/banging the table, crying, feeling like they need to yell, etc). Allow students to independently elect to go to this space when they notice their /brains are telling them they need a break. TEACHER omis. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TIPS FOR USING A CALMING CORNER: Allow students to set a timer for their break (sand timers with different amounts are great), and let them determine if they ve had enough time or need more when the timer is up. As much as possible, have students return to the task/activity they were working on when they needed a break, adding any adaptations or additional supports ας needed to help prevent further frustration. TEACHER omis. SPEECHIEP'.
Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people sitting, people standing, outdoors and brick wall.

node.text:
My baby started Kindergarten today! I’m feeling alllll the feels - 😭🥳😍🤗 
He did great this morning and is so excited! It’s gonna be a great year!!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people sitting, people standing, outdoors and brick wall.
Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child and indoor.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 10, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'INCREASING ACCESSIBILITY BY PLANNING WITH NEURODIVERSITY IN MIND PHYSICALLY STRUCTURE SPACES CLEAR VISUAL SCHEDULES INCORPORATE INTERESTS CLEAR VISUAL EXPECTATIONS VISUALLY STRUCTURE TASKS TEACHER amrs SPEECHIEP'.

node.text:
It can be difficult for teachers to know how they can support neurodivergent students - and I think even harder to find *specific ideas* for how to plan to include everyone into their activities. Which is exactly what @the_neurodivergent_teacher and I bring you today- Specific ideas that can help you right now! 

As always, sharing is caring - let’s get the word out so teachers can support ALL kids! 🌈♾❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 10, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'INCREASING ACCESSIBILITY BY PLANNING WITH NEURODIVERSITY IN MIND PHYSICALLY STRUCTURE SPACES CLEAR VISUAL SCHEDULES INCORPORATE INTERESTS CLEAR VISUAL EXPECTATIONS VISUALLY STRUCTURE TASKS TEACHER amrs SPEECHIEP'.
Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 10, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INCREASING ACCESSIBILITY: CLEAR, VISUAL DAILY SCHEDULE Many students experience anxiety about the unknown or changes to the schedule. We can help reduce this anxiety by clearly communicating the daily schedule, which will answer questions such as: How will know when it's time for lunch? When will my least favorite activities be? How will know if a change is coming? Reduced anxiety will make it easier for students to access their learning and focus on the current task. Some students may benefit from a whole class schedule while others may need individual schedules at their desk. Amrs. SPEECHIEP TEACHER'.
Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text.
Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text.
Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text.
Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo shared by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 09, 2021 tagging @the_neurodivergent_teacher. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'DESIGNING NEURODIVERSITY AFFIRMING RULES EXPECTATIONS AT SCHOOL Recognize all bodies and brains learn and listen in different ways Help students identify the ways their bodies listen and learn Write classroom expectations that teach kids to advocate for their needs Avoid rules that focus on proper procedures over getting needs met Directly teach your class abstract words or phrases in rules Avoid rules that police students' bodies, tones, feelings, etc. TEACHER omis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

node.text:
Excited to share tips with @the_neurodivergent_teacher for designing Neurodiversity affirming rules and expectations at school today! 

Whole Body Listening is so commonly used in classrooms but did you know that it’s NOT helpful for many neurodivergent kids?? It’s not- because everyone learns differently! Click and read though for specific things classroom teachers can do to support all kids and their individuals needs ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 09, 2021 tagging @the_neurodivergent_teacher. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'DESIGNING NEURODIVERSITY AFFIRMING RULES EXPECTATIONS AT SCHOOL Recognize all bodies and brains learn and listen in different ways Help students identify the ways their bodies listen and learn Write classroom expectations that teach kids to advocate for their needs Avoid rules that focus on proper procedures over getting needs met Directly teach your class abstract words or phrases in rules Avoid rules that police students' bodies, tones, feelings, etc. TEACHER omis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'RECOGNIZE ALL BRAINS AND BODIES LEARN AND LISTEN IN DIFFERENT WAYS: We know all kids learn differently, but sometimes our rules do not reflect that knowledge. A common classroom rule is "Whole Body Listening' where children are instructed to sit, look, and be still and quiet while listening and learning. Some kids learn best this way, but this is not true for all kids. Rules should not instruct children to listen in only one way because it is unique to each child! YEACHER omis. SPEECHIEP'.
Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 09, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'WRITE CLASSROOM EXPECTATIONS THAT TEACH KIDS TO ADVOCATE FOR THEIR NEEDS: 1. When you need a break you can... 2. When you need to go to the bathroom, this is how you ask... 3. When you need to move, this is where you can go... 4. When you need water, this is how you ask... 5.If you need a snack, this is how you tell me... TEACHER Amrs. SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'AVOID RULES THAT FOCUS MORE ON PROPER PROCEDURES OVER GETTING NEEDS MET: "You didn't raise your hand to ask to go to the bathroom, so I'm not going to let you go" Many students cannot remember proper procedures when they are trying to get their needs met. Make sure your procedures make things easier not harder to access; and keep executive dysfunction in mind. TEACHER Amis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'DIRECTLY TEACH YOUR CLASS ABSTRACT WORDS OR PHRASES IN RULES: If rules include "Be kind to everyone" or "treat everyone with respect", teach what this means. What is kindness? What is respect? What do they look like in the classroom? Give specific examples. What are some examples of what this does NOT look like? TEACHER Amrs SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'AVOID RULES THA POLICE STUDENTS' BODIES, TONES, FEELINGS, THOUGHTS OR SOCIAL/COMMUNICATION STYLES: Rules such as, "stay positive," "always say hello," "use your words," "ask nicely, 'quiet hands" etc, reinforce the idea that there is only one way to think, communicate, or act which in turn encourages masking. TEACHER Amis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP in Dallas, Texas with @the_neurodivergent_teacher. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TEACHERS CAN SUPPORT A NEURODIVERSE CLASSROOM BY... Designing Neurodiversity Affirming Rules and Expectations Increasing Accessibility by Planning with Neurodiversity in Mind Setting up α Calming Corner Directly Teaching Coping and Regulation Skills TEACHER Amis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

node.text: 🎉 I am teaming up with @the_neurodivergent_teacher this week to bring teachers tips for supporting a neurodiverse classroom!! We will be sharing specific info about all of these topics each day this week so stay tuned! Its gonna be AMAZING!! Let us know, which topic are you most excited to learn about?! 👇🏼

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 05, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Who’s ready for Back to School?!? Okay, we’ll ready or not, it’s time! 🤣

Now, I LOVE themed therapy ❤️ And do you know why?? Here’s just a small piece of the evidence behind my WHY when it comes to using themes for vocab and language in speech! Themes can help students make lasting connections when exposed to vocabulary in a variety of ways- like reading books, dramatic play, and sensory play!
•
Abby @the.type.b.slp and I teamed up to show you how this can be incorporated into a back to school theme! Tons of these ideas are things you can easily put together before the first day, and cost $0! Can’t beat that! Let us know your FREE or low cost back to school ideas in the comments! 👇🏼

HIS 公天九 ISHOM WEre PAIR WITH ANY "GETTING TO KNOW YOU" ACTIVITY TO DISCUSS OUR DIFFERENCES AND OUR SIMILARITIES Seven One Day the Kids from around World MATT LAMOTHE Type 1 BSL mrs.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'BACK TO SCHOOL VOCABULARY I SPY GAME FUN, EASY SPY GAMES GIVES YOU INSIGHT ON THE STUDENTS' VOCABULARY AND SPEECH GOALS WHILE THEY LEARN το NAVIGATE YOUR SPEECH ROOM! Ruler Computer Toys Crayons Break Area Bathroom Desk Tablet/iPad Pencil Sensory Bin(s) Books Schedule Puzzles Games 2 S Posters/ Visuals Snacks Sensory Items Markers mrs.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP on August 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'BACK TO SCHOOL WHAT'S IN THE BACKPACK? GRAB AN OLD CHILDREN'S SIZED BACKPACK, AND FILL WITH SCHOOL SUPPLIES. TAKE TURNS PICKING AN ITEM (DON'T PEEK!), AND DESCRIBE IT το ONE ANOTHER. WHO CAN GUESS WHAT SCHOOL ITEM IT IS?! Snack Toy Game Ruler Crayons Scissors Tablet/iPad Binder Markers Pencil Paper Book T ypeS S Paperclip Notebook Stickers mrs.Q SPEECHIEP'.

Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP in Dallas, Texas. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'DENIAL α Defense Mechanism that is a COMMON response in parents of children with delays and disabilities. How it can Help: Denial can help parents cope with stressful situations by temporarily reducing anxiety How it can Hurt: Prolonged Denial can prevent a child from accessing early and/or appropriate intervention What You Can Do: Recognize that Denial is a powerful thing. If anyone has concerns about your child's development even if you are positive they are wrong, go ahead and schedule an assessment or second opinion -it will only give you more info to help your child. Ams SPEECHIEP'.

node.text:
I know- this is such a hard topic to talk about because parents can be defensive - and professionals can be quick to judge. But- denial is so common and needs to be talked about- It really can help overwhelmed parents while they process information (short term!). But when it becomes long term, it not only adds to stigmas associated with disabilities, but also can deny a child access to needed support. And we want to be able to support our kids! 

As professionals, it’s our job to support parents and help them realize and accept their child may be different. But that can be difficult, time consuming, and frustrating (I get it!). This is just one more reason why I developed my Autism Handbook! I want parents to have access to neurodiversity positive information and feel supported in their processing and emotions. It goes on sale later this month so keep an eye out! ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP in Dallas, Texas. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'IMPROVE EARLY COMMUNICATION BY... Sitting Face to Face Making Play Routines Responding to Attempts to Communicate Following the Child's Lead Using Exaggerated Intonation & Facial Imitating the Child's Sounds and Actions Expressions Amis.Q SPEECHIEP'.

node.text: Want to know some simple tips you can do RIGHT NOW to support communication in young toddlers? You got it!!! Interaction + Engagement + Repetition = the communication trifecta! You can do these with any activity: books, video clips, toys, bath time, any time!! ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Andi Putt, M.S., CCC-SLP in Dallas, Texas. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'SIGNS OF PRESCHOOL LANGUAGE DISORDERS Difficulty with the Following: Receptive: Pointing to named objects or pictures •Answering questions •Following directions Knowing when and how to take turns in a game or conversation Understanding gestures .Understanding longer phrases, or concepts such ας prepositions or pronouns Expressive: Naming objects Asking questions •Combining words and speaking in sentences •Maintaining conversations Using gestures Sharing about experiences Using prepositions and pronouns Amrs SPEECHIEP'.

node.text: It can be difficult for parents and teachers to know when to seek help from a speech language pathologist after that initial stage of learning first words. Speech therapy is commonly misunderstood outside of “speaking words” and “saying sounds correctly” - but language is a HUGE part of what we do! If you have a preschool (or older) child who has difficulty with any of the skills listed below, it’s a good idea to talk to a speech language pathologist! ❤️
